Answer: In 1995, my favourite Elect Engg professor at IITK told our class, 'Cellphones are now being introduced in India. Who is going to use them? Is this technology even relevant to a society like ours?'We know what happened in the next 10-15 years.As an entrepreneur, I have learned the hard way that the most dangerous thing to say is: People will never do 'X'. (E.g., People will never buy glasses online)More than once, I have made such bold predictions only to end up with egg on my face.The truth is that we have no idea how people will behave in the future - how they will shop, eat, date, read, socIn 1995, my favourite Elect Engg professor at IITK told our class, 'Cellphones are now being introduced in India. Who is going to use them? Is this technology even relevant to a society like ours?'We know what happened in the next 10-15 years.As an entrepreneur, I have learned the hard way that the most dangerous thing to say is: People will never do 'X'. (E.g., People will never buy glasses online)More than once, I have made such bold predictions only to end up with egg on my face.The truth is that we have no idea how people will behave in the future - how they will shop, eat, date, read, socialize, or entertain themselves.Once we take a strong point of view, it becomes an ideology and is no longer a hypothesis. We become its proponent and wake up only when the game is over.I will end with a quote from a Yahoo engineer I was talking to in 2006 - 'Gmail has only 5 million users, we (Yahoo Mail) have 30 million. Older people will never switch to Gmail.'Note: It is not my case that you can‚Äôt have a point of view on the future of technology. But remember that it is a hypothesis. Look out for data to validate it.

Answer: How far can technology really go?I think the term ‚Äútechnology‚Äù is interesting when one considers it to represent, to us now anyway, a leading frontier of human innovation. Technology during the various ages of human development is often used to define the age too. When the level of technology progresses too much, we usually refer to that as a different ‚Äúage‚Äù in human history.When one considers how rapidly every field of human knowledge is advancing today, we realize we are ‚Äúbreaking the scale we use to measure ages‚Äù. We‚Äôre not just creating new inventions faster at this point in human history,How far can technology really go?I think the term ‚Äútechnology‚Äù is interesting when one considers it to represent, to us now anyway, a leading frontier of human innovation. Technology during the various ages of human development is often used to define the age too. When the level of technology progresses too much, we usually refer to that as a different ‚Äúage‚Äù in human history.When one considers how rapidly every field of human knowledge is advancing today, we realize we are ‚Äúbreaking the scale we use to measure ages‚Äù. We‚Äôre not just creating new inventions faster at this point in human history, we are at a creative and innovation point of development where the ‚Äúcurve of advancing technologies‚Äù is starting to appear vertical. We don‚Äôt quite know how to describe this situation.I think we need to adopt a more inclusive social contract in society as a whole before our technology can progress beyond what our pop culture science fictions have projected. Frankly, I think ‚Äútechnology‚Äù can take us ‚Äúall the way‚Äù beyond being human, but that type of technology is going require several revolutions in our social contracts between one another to happen. We‚Äôre spending far too much attention on security and warfare, where that attention spent on more productive activities could have ended any reasons for our geopolitical tensions a generation ago.At this point in our development, with the new technologies curve appearing vertical, the only thing holding us back is our maturity as a species.

Answer: Sorry, this is a problematic question. Why wouldn't they, if it's more efficient and kids need to know it. On the other hand, I'm not convinced they lean toward anything sensible. They are just as likely to play with it and talk about it and pretend.Is there some data that establish the premise of this question? Schools lean toward technology?? I have not gotten this impression from anything I've read. My impression is the schools lean toward ignorance and illiteracy. Perhaps I'm too cynical. But I know we have 40 or 50 million functional illiterates. What were their schools leaning toward? ISorry, this is a problematic question. Why wouldn't they, if it's more efficient and kids need to know it. On the other hand, I'm not convinced they lean toward anything sensible. They are just as likely to play with it and talk about it and pretend.Is there some data that establish the premise of this question? Schools lean toward technology?? I have not gotten this impression from anything I've read. My impression is the schools lean toward ignorance and illiteracy. Perhaps I'm too cynical. But I know we have 40 or 50 million functional illiterates. What were their schools leaning toward? I know that students reach college not knowing who won the Civil War or where Alaska is.Finally, I don't trust any one answer, yes or no. I don't trust technology, yes or no. I'm continually struck by the crucial importance of the people at the top. If they're teaching with chalk on old blackboards, but their hearts and minds are sincerely engaged, the kids will do fine. But if you have some slick Progressive ideologues in a $10 million school with all the latest gadgets from Apple, nothing is going to happen.If you ask me why I'm so sure, I will tell youJust one final observation. I'm also continually struck by the use of sophistry throughout education. People throw up false arguments, maybe about technology, maybe about one-size-fits-all, maybe about creativity, maybe about not enough money, maybe about videogames, maybe about parents, maybe about the price of rice in China. The point is, if somebody wants to move you in a particular direction, they will devise arguments they think will impress you or weaken your conviction. Often it seems to me that the arguments aren't persuasive, they don't even seem to be serious. But that's one of the reasons our Education Establishment has motivation to dumb down both students and parents. These students and parents will not put up much resistance.(And out there in the real world, the political world, we see this nonsense every day. Even liberals must be struck by the fact that Trump could show up in black shoes and this could prove he's evil; and the next day he could show up in brown shoes and this could prove he's evil. There is a complete disconnect between the so-called argument and the so-called proof. Even editors of major newspapers seem incapable of intelligent thought. Our school system did not try to teach this, apparently. Almost 100 years ago H. L. Mencken said:‚ÄúThe most erroneous assumption is to the effect that the aim of public education is to fill the young of the species with knowledge and awaken their intelligence, and so make them fit to discharge the duties of citizenship in an enlightened and independent manner. Nothing could be further from the truth. The aim of public education is not to spread enlightenment at all; it is simply to reduce as many individuals as possible to the same safe level, to breed and train a standardized citizenry, to put down dissent and originality. That is its aim in the United States, whatever the pretensions of politicians, pedagogues and other such mountebanks, and that is its aim everywhere else.‚ÄùCan you disagree? Personally, I feel it is true. I wish desperately it were not.)

Usually, there are teams that work on the same project each contributing to a whole that develops the new tech. When you look at even one area of technology, say for example aeronautics, it requires not only an understanding of the engineering of plane designs because say you will want to make a faster plane or one that can fly longer distances or a new kind of jet engine. You will probably need the help of a chemist or material engineer to create lightweight strong materials to keep the plane together under moIt would require someone to be multidisciplinary in a way that we do not see today. Usually, there are teams that work on the same project each contributing to a whole that develops the new tech. When you look at even one area of technology, say for example aeronautics, it requires not only an understanding of the engineering of plane designs because say you will want to make a faster plane or one that can fly longer distances or a new kind of jet engine. You will probably need the help of a chemist or material engineer to create lightweight strong materials to keep the plane together under more extreme conditions. Also, when it comes to the electronics and computer systems that make the plane flyable requires special knowledge. So even if you had a genius IQ unless you are able to have a wide range of specialties it would be hard to create new tech completely on your own.Unless you had access to AI like Tony Stark in the Iron man movies, then maybe.

Answer: Luck. Always pick luck if you get the option to pick your own superpower.Luck is the single most broken superpower ever. One day of pure luck would set you up for your entire life. Buy a lottery ticket, send out a job application, and go out to the club. By the end of a single day you have more money than you could ever spend in your life, your dream job, and have met the love of your life.Honestly, that would be if you felt ambitious. Chances are you wouldn‚Äôt even have to do that much. You could simply walk to the mailbox and things would just naturally work out so you would come back with thLuck. Always pick luck if you get the option to pick your own superpower.Luck is the single most broken superpower ever. One day of pure luck would set you up for your entire life. Buy a lottery ticket, send out a job application, and go out to the club. By the end of a single day you have more money than you could ever spend in your life, your dream job, and have met the love of your life.Honestly, that would be if you felt ambitious. Chances are you wouldn‚Äôt even have to do that much. You could simply walk to the mailbox and things would just naturally work out so you would come back with the deed to a brand new house.The wonderful thing about luck is that it is a passive power. Things just naturally happen in your favor. Let‚Äôs say you decide that you want the power of creating things from your own mind. You want a car? Well try to make one and see how quickly you will run into some sort of manufacturing issue because you don‚Äôt know the specifics of some part of the car. But with luck there is no learning curve, there‚Äôs no unexpected surprises. Everything just goes your way.There is no more advantageous power than luck. Always pick luck if you have the option to pick a power.

Answer: Of course, the others are correct in that the apes, especially chimps and gorillas would create the most advanced of civilisations, being strong and well suited for advancement, but I will point out that by far the most dangerous species would become the ants.For this scenario, let‚Äôs say all ants become hyper intelligent, but remain loyal to the colony and queen ant.Firstly, the sheer number of ants that exist on Earth. The best estimate I could find (BBC Four) stated that there are 100 trillion ants on Earth and they have spread to every single continent on Earth. Ants are absolutely remarkabOf course, the others are correct in that the apes, especially chimps and gorillas would create the most advanced of civilisations, being strong and well suited for advancement, but I will point out that by far the most dangerous species would become the ants.For this scenario, let‚Äôs say all ants become hyper intelligent, but remain loyal to the colony and queen ant.Firstly, the sheer number of ants that exist on Earth. The best estimate I could find (BBC Four) stated that there are 100 trillion ants on Earth and they have spread to every single continent on Earth. Ants are absolutely remarkable and these are some thing they have already done, without the intelligence boost this question gives them.Humans have build cities, and some intelligent animals may have cobbled together a makeshift shelter for safety, but ants have built massive colonies underground, safe from most hazards that lie above, with rooms dedicated to specific purposes like storage, mating, nurseries, farms and even garbage disposal areas like we have with landfills, all connected with tunnels that ensure good ventilation.A group of scientists unearthed an ant colony that covered over 50 square metres of space and was 8 metres deep. The colony must have moved 80 tonnes of soil to build it. This would be a New York City for the ants to build. But, we have discovered supercolonies, built by these ants, most notably the Argentine Ant. One supercolony in Europe spread across 6000 km, formed by multiple ant colonies joining and working together, with billions and billions of workers, basically forming their own countries. That‚Äôs not all. Argentine Ants from different supercolonies are sociable to other Argentine Ants from other parts of the world, essentially creating a mega-colony that has spread worldwide.Ants are also the only animals other than humans, to go to war with each other and other kinds like termites. The Army Ants of South America band together into a gigantic unit, moving as a united front and tearing through everything that cannot get away. When the Army Ants start to move, birds take off, insects flee, snakes go into the water or into their burrows, even jaguars and horses turn and run when they spot the ants.Army Ants can eat an entire horse. Compare a horse to yourself. There, you see why everything runs. Army Ants also build things with themselves. Have to cross from one tree to another? Have to cross a small stream? The Army Ants build bridges with their own bodies, ensuring no obstacle can stop their movements.Ants have also been spotted using deceptions. When two ants from different species meet in the wild, they either duke it out instantly or size each other up to see how dangerous that ant is. Ants have been seen standing on higher ground or pebbles to look bigger than their opponent. That‚Äôs not all. Ants use tactics in war too. They put the weakest and crippled ants at the front lines to suicidally charge and overwhelm the target before the larger soldiers come in to finish the target effortlessly. This prevents the valuable soldiers from being injured or killed unnecessarily. This brings me to another point. Ants act as a superorganism, not as one. They are absolutely ready to die for the colony‚Äôs survival, there is no retreat, just endless waves and waves until the ants destroy the enemy, meaning large colonies almost always destroy other insects or animals. Ant wars are pitted at massive scales, since both sides are suicidally ready to throw out millions upon millions of lives to ensure victory, like the Argentine-Fire Ant War in California, for control of not just a small area, but practically the entire state. This war has already lasted years and to my knowledge, is still ongoing.I have just given you an infodump on just how crazily similar ants are to humans and how they have thrived for longer than the dinosaurs and spread to all continents other than Antarctica. How they construct country-sized colonies and wage massive wars with tactics. How they work as one. Now, imagine they all gain intelligence. Imagine they all become as smart as humans. They would take longer to get to our standards than the apes, but they would easily become the largest threat to all the intelligent animals. The superorganism they act as ensures little room for error and no personal nature will get in the way. They could learn to construct, become deadlier, form armies to attack cities and wherever intelligent animals stay. I assume that the supercolonies could join as one, alliances between ant colonies that consist of trillions of ants could be formed and there would be no betrayal, just a ruthlessness and bravery never before seen. Ants will find ways to be resistant to pesticides and water attacks. All intelligent animals would immediately stop fighting themselves and realise just how dangerous the ants became.Then‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know. Maybe World War Ants happens or something.Sources:Edit:The stretch of the 6000 km supercolony. The black dots are Argentine Ants and the white dots are another supercolony hostile to the Argentine Ants.

Answer: Not alone. The ‚Äúsolitary genius working alone‚Äù is a one in a billion event (and arguably nobody works in a vacuum even then), and when it happens the person invents ONE thing, not a whole slew of them.When I saw the TV showThe rationale I imagined (because I do this foNot alone. The ‚Äúsolitary genius working alone‚Äù is a one in a billion event (and arguably nobody works in a vacuum even then), and when it happens the person invents ONE thing, not a whole slew of them.When I saw the TV showThe rationale I imagined (because I do this for fun) was that the mad scientist had made ONE big discovery‚Äîthe ability to shift his brain into a much higher gear. (I have no idea if the TV show went this route or a different one.)But to bring this into the real world‚Äîif you posit a person with super-intelligence, that person would:For example, I like to imagine that Tony Stark‚Äôs brilliance was genuine, but his true superpower was in his first and greatest breakthrough: creating J.A.R.V.I.S. a true AI, who serves as a dramatic force multiplier, effectively replacing large teams of scientists and engineers.It‚Äôs a lot more plausible to believe ONE breakthrough that has effects leading to many more, than to imagine someone who could have breakthrough after breakthrough in completely separate fields. I know we‚Äôre used to montages in movies but even so the character should be like 50 years older every time they made a new breakthrough because it would take that long to become an expert in another area.Tony Stark becoming an expert on gamma radiation overnight in a movie is demonstrating superhuman intelligence, because there wouldn‚Äôt even be time to physically read evenNow if you posit a different sort of breakthrough, such as ‚Äúsuperhuman study skills‚Äù, well we don‚Äôt actually have a rationale for that. You‚Äôd need something or someone to take care of the millions of details and labor even if you were a brilliant ‚Äúidea generator.‚ÄùOr you‚Äôd need to be able to download textbooksI may have given this some thought at some point. ;)

Answer: Depends on what you define as ‚Äúlate Roman army". The Byzantine Empire was the successor to the Roman Empire when it used to be called the Eastern Roman Empire. Actually, in real life I doubt anyone stopped calling people in the former empire Roman's.So there is a difference between the western Roman Empire that collapsed in 476 AD and the eastern Roman Empire that collapsed in 1453, which by definition would be around the time of the pre-gunpowder Medieval period. Guess what, the Romans in the medieval times were actually very good. The fact they lasted so long is testament to their resilienceDepends on what you define as ‚Äúlate Roman army". The Byzantine Empire was the successor to the Roman Empire when it used to be called the Eastern Roman Empire. Actually, in real life I doubt anyone stopped calling people in the former empire Roman's.So there is a difference between the western Roman Empire that collapsed in 476 AD and the eastern Roman Empire that collapsed in 1453, which by definition would be around the time of the pre-gunpowder Medieval period. Guess what, the Romans in the medieval times were actually very good. The fact they lasted so long is testament to their resilience. They did not stop evolving either. The 15th century Romans would've run circles (literally) around Imperial legions in terms of ranged weapons and cavalry but probably would've had a hard time lasting long in melee combat with Imperial legions.Armies adapt to the enemies they were fighting and so as the Romans went east they had to adapt from fighting infantry based armies to cavalry and archer based armies. You can also see changes in the imperial legion in regards to how expansion and recruitment changed the composition of its armies.Late republic Roman empire legions were precursors to the imperial legions which used the same tactics in melee combat. The Roman legions became professional through almost constant warfare. Not many medieval armies had as many professionals trained as in the photo. Knights could be useful but if 90% of your army were just conscript levies that stood around with a spear and not much else, then they aren't going to have much of a chance against a whole army of professionals.These show that not every man in a medieval army was a head-to-toe plate-armored knight. Many weren't much better armored than ancient era legionaries, much less heavy infantry or heavy cavalry of the Byzantine empire.

This invention could remove language barriers and make travelling - and doing business with other cultures ‚Äì much easier. With these earbuds, someone could be standing in front of you speaking French, and the earbuds will feed you the English translation. Answer: Our current level of science and technology is about 800 to 1000 years behind where we should be.After the fall of Rome Empire in the 5th century, western society returned to an era of barbarism; feudal warlords, serfs and rest of the population was totally illiterate. (Except for a few priests who were just barely literate enough to read one book and one book only.) Western culture was totally boned at that point.Fortunately, the classical knowledge of the Greeks and Romans was kept alive by the Islamic nations who were truly excellent mathematicians and philosophers but mediocre technologistOur current level of science and technology is about 800 to 1000 years behind where we should be.After the fall of Rome Empire in the 5th century, western society returned to an era of barbarism; feudal warlords, serfs and rest of the population was totally illiterate. (Except for a few priests who were just barely literate enough to read one book and one book only.) Western culture was totally boned at that point.Fortunately, the classical knowledge of the Greeks and Romans was kept alive by the Islamic nations who were truly excellent mathematicians and philosophers but mediocre technologists and lousy scientists. The Chinese were also very advanced but they completely isolated themselves from the rest of the world. As did India and later on Japan.It wasn‚Äôt until the 15th Century Renaissance that western civilization started to advance again. And it wasn‚Äôt until the Scientific Revolution and the first Industrial Revolution that the world entered the modern era and changed dramatically.If we had not fallen so far behind, most of our current social problems would be solved long ago and our civilization would probably be out colonizing the entire solar system.

Production electric cars? Commercial air travel? Satellites?Computers? Personal computers? The Internet? Social Media? Smartphones?Blockchain? 3D printing? 4D printing?Genetic engineering? CERN? Exoplanets? Nanomaterials? Drones?Doubling of the average human life span? Cryptocurrency? Smart cities? AI?And that's just in a single century, 1% of the time frame you're asking about.And the pace of technological advancImagine asking that same question a hundred years ago, in 1918.Could you have even begun to imagine the changes in just one hundred years?Radio? TV? Nuclear weapons? Production cars? Production electric cars? Commercial air travel? Satellites?Computers? Personal computers? The Internet? Social Media? Smartphones?Blockchain? 3D printing? 4D printing?Genetic engineering? CERN? Exoplanets? Nanomaterials? Drones?Doubling of the average human life span? Cryptocurrency? Smart cities? AI?And that's just in a single century, 1% of the time frame you're asking about.And the pace of technological advancement is not constant- it's accelerating, and ever more rapidly.And so, I think it's fair to say that it's not really possible to have any idea- and that the advances will be essentially incomprehensible to anyone alive today.
